ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about Yale's history and the development of the American university.
A broad overview of some of the most important people of Yale University and an understanding of the University through the ages.
cohesive history between Yale and the United States

This course helped expose me to the fascinating and multi-faceted history of Yale and those who have been a part of it. I gained a deep appreciation for the institution and a love for its history. Now, when I walk through campus, I can reflect on those who came before me and built the place I benefit from today.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course jumps around a lot. While that makes it interesting and touches on a lot of different subjects, it can feel unfocused and difficult to find a common thread.

This had the potential to be a very interesting class but it was fairly disorganized and did not have a lot of structure. It was mostly just listening to Professor Gitlin lecture, and oftentimes just talk about his college days at Yale. There was also not a lot of feedback or guidance for assignments, so grading is pretty subjective.

Strengths: Prof Gitlin is one-of-a-kind. Assignments were a lot of fun.

Weaknesses: A bit slow at times, dense readings, could have been better class discussions.
strengths are Gitlin! weaknesses are poor organization.

Strengths- Professor Gitlin is a joy, the course covers a lot of interesting material and the students are all very engaged
Weaknesses- none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but you have to be aware that this course is unlike many other history courses at Yale.
Absolutely! Everyone shld take this course.

Interesting class and Gitlin is interesting and tells a lot of stories, but sometimes the seminars drag on and it is clear that a lot of people aren't doing the reading. He's a super sweet guy, but the class can feel long.
It was sort of enjoyable but not a necessary class to take before graduating.

Of course! This class is so fun for any senior or history major looking to learn more about Yale before graduation. I can honestly say I view campus differently because of this class. Also, Prof. G LOVES Yale and its students so he will make sure you have a good time.

Look, this course often times gets rave reviews from people that I think mostly are there to have a good time with friends more than anything else. I love this class, and I think it is extremely (and unfortunately) unique amongst Yale's course selection. But I definitely wouldn't recommend it to everyone. I think too many people join this class because they think it's easy and not because they are just genuinely interested in learning the material. It's too bad because I think sometimes people were distracted in class which made the experience less pleasant for everyone else. That being said, if you do actually care about the subject and what to learn more, take this class. It is so much fun and such a rarity amongst other Yale classes.
yes! it's fun but not super intense.

Yes, absolutely take this course. The workload is light but you stay engaged and interested so long as you keep up with readings. The final paper is very open to what you want to write about so it can be made to be very fun.
